Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Environmental Outcomes in Multiple Spatial Scales

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1434022
John Logan
Juyoung Lee
Brown University

This dissertation investigates how a spatialized political economy shapes the distribution of environmental hazards across neighborhoods. Specifically, it examines toxic chemicals released by chemical manufacturing facilities. Previous quantitative studies have focused on the racial and socioeconomic characteristics of neighborhoods to understand environmental inequality. However, one cannot fully understand neighborhood-level variation in environmental hazards without also taking into account social processes and decisions at the city, state, and national levels. This dissertation will analyze information for 2000-2010 from the Toxic Release Inventory Program, U.S. Census, and other data sources, and it will examine how corporations, governments, and environmental movement groups influenced local environmental outcomes in this period. This dissertation will contribute to understanding environmental inequality, and it will enhance the literatures on neighborhood effects, social movements, and organizational behavior.

Broader Impact

Environmental inequalities reflect underlying social inequities that are typically tied to race and class. At the same time, environmental inequalities generate other types of inequality, such as health disparities, and in this way they reinforce preexisting racial and class differences. The multilevel perspective taken by this dissertation will identify the conditions under which disadvantaged neighborhoods are likely to suffer from environmental hazards. It will have policy implications for governments, environmental organizations, and corporations at the local, regional and national scale, with the goal of improving the quality of life of marginalized social groups in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation research project aims to provide multilevel explanations of environmental inequalities across U.S. neighborhoods. With a multilevel perspective, I not only shed light on the racial and socioeconomic characteristics of neighborhoods but also on the larger social processes shaped by governments, corporations, and environmental movement groups. My overarching question is how the operations of state governments, corporations, and movement groups, in conjunction with neighborhood characteristics, determine the distribution of environmental hazards from industrial facilities across places. I address this question in the chemical manufacturing industry, which is among the most responsible sectors for the release of toxic chemicals in this country.  

This project sought support from the NSF for acquiring quantitative data on broader social processes beyond the neighborhoods. Specifically, the NSF grant was used for purchasing corporate family tree data and for collecting data on environmental movement groups. These data has been analyzed alongside the Environmental Protection Agency's Toxic Release Inventory Program and neighborhood-level demographic data from the U.S. Census, both of which are commonly used in quantitative studies on environmental inequality. In doing so, my dissertation intends to expand the primary focus of environmental inequality studies beyond neighborhood characteristics into the large-scale determinants of local environmental outcomes.

While my dissertation research project is still in progress, I have found significant evidence that the modus operandi of large companies and state governments has differential environmental impacts. First, contemporary large companies own their business operations at numerous locations, and structure them as a multi-tiered hierarchical form. In this context, my dissertation examined what kinds of business sites are more likely to carry out polluting industrial activities and to generate greater environmental hazards, paying particular attention to where these business operations are positioned in the corporate hierarchy and where they are geographically located in relation to their headquarter companies.

My statistical analysis demonstrated that hazardous industrial activities are concentrated among business sites that are hierarchically and geographically distant from their headquarter companies. With respect to environmental performance, higher levels of chemical hazards were released in industrial plants that occupied lower levels in the corporate hierarchy. Non-local plants were less attentive to state environmental policies, and generated greater environmental hazards than local firms in strong environmental states. In addition, in line with the environmental injustice arguments, corporate sites in disadvantaged neighborhoods were more likely to engage in polluting business operations and to generate more serious pollution.

Second, this project also investigated how state governments influenced the environmental practices of industrial plants during the first decade of twenty-first century. In particular, facilities' environmental performance was improved in states where governments were inclined to favor proenvironmental policies. However, strict environmental policies did not contribute to improving the environmental performance of facilities located in poor neighborhoods; rather, poor neighborhoods in strong proenvironmental states experienced an increase in environmental hazards from 2002 and 2012. This implies that, if environmental policies do not consider environmental inequality issues, strict environmental policies may impose greater environmental burdens on disadvantaged social groups.
